“人们对短期内的债务上限过于兴奋”，富国银行的哈维说
关门铃：加时赛

标准普尔 500 指数和纳斯达克综合指数由于华尔街交易员继续关注债务上限谈判，周四股市上涨。

标准普尔 500 指数上涨 0.6%，纳斯达克综合指数上涨 1.1%。 道琼斯工业平均指数 宝洁跌逾2%拖累跌11点 .

众议院议长凯文麦卡锡周四表示， 他对国会谈判代表能够在下周众议院投票前及时达成协议持乐观态度。

“我看到了我们可以达成协议的途径，”麦卡锡说。 “而且我认为我们现在有了一个结构，每个人都在努力工作，我的意思是，我们每天工作两到三次，然后回去获得更多数据。”

据财政部长珍妮特耶伦称，他发表评论的时间只有两周，直到 6 月 1 日，这是美国可能违约的最早一天。 KKM Financial 首席执行官 Jeff Kilburg 表示，交易员已经能够“看穿”围绕债务上限谈判的一些戏剧性事件。

“我个人认为债务上限是一个很大的噪音，但我认为投资者甚至交易员都很难忽视，”基尔伯格说。 “我对市场持乐观态度，但也对我们将找到前进的方法持乐观态度。美国政府永远不会真正放弃违约。”

零售巨头沃尔玛帮助市场，在其强劲的财务报告的支持下上涨了约 1%。该公司在第一季度的每股收益和收入均超出了华尔街的预期，并上调了对全年业绩的预期。

但在达拉斯联邦储备银行行长洛里洛根表示最新的经济数据并不支持暂停加息后，市场情绪受到抑制。她指出，6 月份的政策决定将基于尚未公布的通胀和就业数据。

LPL Financial 首席全球策略师昆西·克罗斯比 (Quincy Krosby) 表示：“由于金融市场一直在关注债务上限谈判的状况，广播中也出现了美联储发言人的猛烈攻击，他们似乎的任务是向市场传递信息。” . “消息表明，美联储目前没有计划今年降息，但现在也引入了在 6 月 13 日至 14 日会议上再次加息的可能性。”

1 分钟前

高盛称人工智能是未来十年利润率的最大推动力之一

高盛表示，人工智能的顺风可能会在未来十年显着提高利润率。

“人工智能是对利润率最大的潜在长期支持，”这家华尔街公司在最近给客户的一份报告中表示。 “我们经济学家的生产力估计表明，人工智能可以在十年内将净利润率提高近 400 个基点。”

高盛预测，在未来十年内，广泛采用将使美国的生产率每年增长 1.5 个百分点。

“根据生产率增长与企业盈利能力之间的历史关系，这种提振可能会提振标准普尔 500 指数在其他条件相同的情况下，这十年的净利润率大约增加了 4 个百分点，”高盛说。

尽管有这些近期的利好因素，但高盛指出，围绕政府政策和广泛采用的不确定性依然存在，削弱了其预测人工智能对企业利润的长期影响的能力。

— 萨曼莎·苏宾

8 分钟前

纽约证券交易所上涨股领跌股进入收盘

纽约证券交易所的上涨股在交易还剩不到一小时的时候比下跌股略有优势。约 1,500 家在纽约证券交易所上市的股票上涨，而其他 1,300 家股票下跌。

— 弗雷德·英伯特

13 分钟前

英国《金融时报》称，卡尔·伊坎说他做空市场是个错误

长期投资者卡尔·伊坎向英国《金融时报》承认，他做空市场是一个错误，这让他损失了数十亿美元。

根据英国《金融时报》根据监管文件进行的分析，自 2017 年以来，维权投资者在看跌押注或对冲头寸中损失了近 90 亿美元。

“我一直告诉人们，没有人能够真正选择短期或中期市场，”伊坎告诉英国《金融时报》。 “也许我近年来犯了一个错误，没有坚持自己的建议。”

——李云

32 分钟前

标准普尔 500 指数和纳斯达克综合指数在收盘前继续上涨

标准普尔 500 指数和纳斯达克综合指数当投资者进入交易的最后一个小时时，他们熬夜了。

标准普尔 500 指数上涨 0.4%，而纳斯达克指数有望收高 1%。道指下跌 0.2%。

— 亚历克斯·哈林

1小时前

达纳·特尔西 (Dana Telsey) 表示，消费者正在购买必需品并寻找价值

消费者关心的是购买必需品和寻找价值，这帮助了沃尔玛 Telsey Advisory 首席执行官达纳·特尔西 (Dana Telsey) 在接受 CNBC 采访时表示，公司的最新财报。这家大型零售商公布了第一季度的收益和收入，并提高了全年的预期。

她在接受“ Squawk on the Street ”采访时表示，不仅其 60% 的销售额来自杂货，而且沃尔玛还受益于消费者从品牌转向更便宜的选择。

“你看看他们提供的价值，你看看地点的便利性，他们用数字技术做了什么，这一切都很好地结束了，”特尔西说。

她补充说，这个财报季还表明，消费者正在返回商店并花钱购买食品和体验，例如旅行。

——米歇尔·福克斯

1小时前

Roundhill Investments 推出专注于生成人工智能的 ETF

随着生成人工智能越来越受欢迎，Roundhill Investments 正在为希望顺应这一趋势的投资者推出一款交易所交易基金。

主动管理的 ETF，被称为 Roundhill Generative AI & Technology ETF (CHAT)，持有大量受益于近期 AI 顺风的名称。顶级持股包括受欢迎的芯片制造商Nvidia , 先进微设备 , 字母表 , 微软和C3.ai .

— 萨曼莎·苏宾

2小时前

嘉信理财股票在预期的夏季动荡之前买入，德意志银行表示

德意志银行重申对嘉信理财的买入评级周四股票，指出该公司可以在更具挑战性的宏观经济背景下坚持下去。

“我们对 SCHW 资产负债表存款下降速度近期有所改善感到鼓舞，客户现金分类继续放缓。4 月份核心资产负债表存款下降速度好于我们的预期，”德意志银行分析师 Brian Bedell 表示.

对更广泛的银行业流动性的担忧给嘉信理财的股票带来压力，该股自 2023 年初以来已下跌约 38.5%。

CNBC Pro 订阅者可以在此处阅读全文。

— 布赖恩·埃文斯

2小时前

纳斯达克 100 指数中大约一半的公司仍较 52 周高点低 20% 或更多

纳斯达克 100 指数中有 51 只股票 ，或大约一半，仍较周四的 52 周高点低 20% 或更多。电动汽车制造商Rivian 和清醒分别比高点低 67% 和 66%。 特斯拉减少了 44.5%。 亚马逊还有大约 20% 的时间。

随后的其他名称包括： Enphase , 京东 , 缩放视频 , 现代 , 贝宝 , 缩放器 , 人群罢工 , 数据狗 , 吉利德和好市多 .

然而，34 个名称（约占该指数的 33%）距离其 52 周高点不到 5%，其中包括Intuitive Surgical , 英伟达 , 网飞 , 露露柠檬和百事可乐 .

Mega-cap tech 引领这一群体。 微软和字母表距离高点不到 1%，而Apple 和元大约有 1% 的折扣。

— 吉娜·弗兰科拉 (Gina Francolla)、塔纳亚·马歇尔 (Tanaya Macheel)

3小时前

Palantir 股价飙升 11%，Cathie Wood 大举入股

数据分析软件供应商Palantir周四上涨超过 11%，将其本月迄今涨幅推高至 45% 以上。

周四的涨势是在披露方舟投资公司的凯西伍德大量买入该股后出现的。这位受欢迎的投资者为她的旗舰方舟创新 ETF购买了 912,193 股周三。她还为她的另外两个基金购买了大约 350,000 美元。

在季度收益强于预期后，本月早些时候 Palantir 的股票受到提振。

Palantir，1 日图

——李云

3小时前

股票在午盘交易中涨幅最大

以下是午盘涨幅最大的一些股票：

  • 沃尔玛 — 这家大型零售商的股票小幅上涨，此前该公司公布了第一财季的收益和收入。沃尔玛还上调了全年业绩指引。然而，其调整后的第二财季盈利指引低于预期。
  • 沐浴及美体用品 — 在其第一财季收益超出预期后，这家零售商的股价上涨了 9% 以上。该公司还上调了全年业绩指引。 Bath & Body Works 报告调整后每股收益为 33 美分，而 Refinitiv 调查的分析师估计每股收益为 26 美分。该公司 14 亿美元的收入符合预期。
  • 联邦快递 — 这家航运巨头的股价在午盘交易中上涨 1.7%。 德意志银行一天前上调了联邦快递股票的目标价，并重申了买入评级，理由是该公司 6 月 20 日的季度业绩有可能在强劲的前瞻指引下帮助提振股价。

完整列表可在此处找到。

— 金哈京

3小时前

信息技术和通信服务股领涨标普 500 指数

信息技术和通信服务股拉动标普 500指数进入会议的积极领域。

这是大盘指数 11 个板块中表现最好的两个板块，信息技术板块上涨 1.6%，非必需消费品板块上涨 1.2%。相比之下，该指数整体上涨了 0.3%。

新思科技和Cadence 设计系统领涨信息技术板块，涨幅分别超过 7% 和 5%。芯片相关个股美光 , 英伟达和应用材料也是该行业表现最好的公司之一。

拍两张和Netflix 是非必需消费品领域表现最好的公司，涨幅分别超过 12% 和 9%。 Netflix 的举动是在它向广告商介绍之后，而 Take-Two 的举动是在其收益报告的背后。

非必需消费品板块是周四交易时段唯一上涨的板块，上涨 0.8%。公用事业是周四表现最差的板块，下跌 1%，只有一个（ WEC Energy ) 的 30 只股票位于持平线上方。

从本周迄今的变化来看，信息技术、消费服务和非必需消费品行业也是前三名。

— 亚历克斯·哈林

4 小时前

宝洁公司被 Truist 降级

Truist 降级Procter & Gamble 周四从买入持股，并将目标价从每股 165 美元下调至 155 美元。

“我们相信该公司在重新调整其产品组合、削减约 10B 美元的间接费用和其他成本以及在过去五年中改善投资者情绪方面做得非常出色。但是，我们现在认为该股票目前的估值充分反映了这些转变努力，”分析师 Bill Chappell 在给客户的一份报告中写道。

“我们只是相信 [the] 股票将在未来几个季度处于持有模式，下行风险增加，”他补充道。

宝洁公司股价周四下跌 1.8%，今年以来小幅上涨。

——米歇尔·福克斯

4 小时前

Netflix 股价上涨 8%

网飞在这家流媒体巨头向广告商进行前期介绍后，其股价周四暴涨约 8%。

在周三举行的活动中，这家媒体公司透露其新的广告支持层拥有近 500 万月活跃用户。

华尔街似乎普遍持积极态度，摩根大通重申其增持评级，并表示其对股票的看法正变得“逐渐积极”。

Netflix 股价大涨

— 萨曼莎·苏宾

5小时前

麦卡锡表示，他对谈判代表能够在下周投票前及时就债务上限达成协议持乐观态度

在众议院议长凯文麦卡锡周四表示他乐观地认为国会谈判代表可以在下周众议院投票前及时就债务上限达成协议后，主要股指走高。

“我看到了我们可以达成协议的途径，”麦卡锡在国会大厦对记者说。 “而且我认为我们现在有了一个结构，每个人都在努力工作，我的意思是，我们每天工作两到三次，然后回去获得更多数据。”

— 克里斯蒂娜·威尔基

5小时前

科技巨头、芯片制造商帮助提振纳斯达克综合指数

纳斯达克综合指数在周四早盘交易中保持 0.5% 的涨幅。

科技股指数受到信息技术和通信服务股的提振，其中亚马逊的股票和Netflix 最后分别上涨 2% 和 8%。大科技股微软 , 苹果 , 字母表也走高了。

芯片股为纳斯达克指数提供了另一条支撑， 英伟达涨幅超过 2%。 美光科技因有消息称它正在帮助日本制造芯片而暴涨近 5%。 美满科技 , 应用材料和林研究均增加了 2%。

新思科技和Take-Two Interactive 在财报公布后分别飙升 7% 和 10% 以上。软件股CrowdStrike , 数据狗和工作日也有收获。

— 萨曼莎·苏宾

5小时前

道指早盘落后

道指是早盘三大指数中表现最差的，下跌约 0.2%。

宝洁公司 , 雪佛龙 , 沃尔格林和联合健康由于每家公司的跌幅都超过 1%，所有这些都对蓝筹股的平均水平构成压力。

沃尔玛和英特尔帮助提振了 30 只股票指数，每只股票的涨幅均超过 2%。在零售巨头沃尔玛第一季度超出华尔街预期并给出乐观指引后，其股价上涨。

道琼斯指数的 1 天图表

— 亚历克斯·哈林

5小时前

4 月份领先指标下降 0.6%，出现“温和衰退”迹象

美国大型企业联合会的领先经济指数在 4 月份下降了 0.6%，表明美国经济状况进一步恶化。

尽管该指数与道琼斯的估计一致，但仍表明增长放缓和未来可能出现衰退。

“重要的是，LEI 继续警告今年经济衰退，”董事会商业周期指标高级经理 Justyna Zabinska-La Monica 说。 “世界大型企业联合会预测，经济活动将从第二季度开始收缩，到 2023 年中期将出现温和衰退。”

LEI 关注 10 个组成部分，包括申请失业救济人数、制造业指标和金融市场基准，如债券收益率和标准普尔 500 指数。

——杰夫考克斯

5小时前

瑞银在季度业绩公布前上调航运巨头的目标价

瑞银上调联邦快递目标价周三，该公司表示，预计下个月的季度业绩将超过市场普遍预期。该股在周四的交易中上涨超过 2%。

德意志银行分析师表示：“我们相信联邦快递下个月即将公布的业绩可能会对股价产生积极的推动作用。我们认为本季度本身几乎没有风险，我们对 2024 年盈利的潜力和相对于市场普遍预期的指引持非常乐观的态度。” Amrit Mehrotra 说。

联邦快递将于 6 月 20 日公布季度业绩。CNBC Pro 订阅者可以在此处阅读完整的瑞银电话会议。

— 布赖恩·埃文斯

6小时前

道琼斯指数、标准普尔 500 指数开盘下跌

道指和标准普尔 500 指数周四均以红色开盘。

道琼斯指数下跌 0.2%，而标准普尔 500 指数略低于持平水平。 纳斯达克综合指数另一方面，上涨了0.2%。

— 亚历克斯·哈林

6小时前

达拉斯联储主席：经济数据还不能证明暂停加息是合理的

达拉斯联邦储备银行行长洛里·洛根周四表示， 目前的经济数据并不能证明央行在 6 月的下一次会议上不加息。

“在过去 10 次联邦公开市场委员会会议上每次都上调联邦基金利率目标区间后，我们取得了一些进展，”她在为圣安东尼奥对银行家的演讲准备好的讲话稿中表示。 “未来几周的数据仍可能表明不参加会议是合适的。不过，截至今天，我们还没有做到这一点。”

在她发表讲话后，期货走低。

— 杰夫考克斯

7 小时前

申请失业救济人数意外下降；费城制造业改善

上周首次申请失业救济人数意外下降，表明劳动力市场仍然有些吃紧。

美国劳工部报告称，截至 5 月 13 日当周的首次申请总计 242,000 份，比前一周减少 22,000 份，低于道琼斯估计的 250,000 份。续请失业金人数微跌至 179.9 万人，低于 FactSet 估计的 182.9 万人。

其他经济消息方面， 费城联储制造业指数升至-10.4，上升29个百分点，好于预期的-20。

然而，该指数衡量的是报告扩张的公司与出现收缩的公司的百分比，仍然显示该地区该行业正在下滑。

——杰夫考克斯

7 小时前

沃尔玛、Take-Two Interactive 成为开市前最大的推动者

近年来，Tread+ 跑步机一直是围绕 Peloton 的安全问题的核心。 自 2021 年一名幼儿在 Tread+ 跑步机下死亡后，该跑步机的销售已经停止。

Peloton 和 CPSC 在一份联合声明中表示，自召回以来，又报告了 279 起事件和 61 起受伤报告。

该公司在一份新闻稿中表示，该安全防护装置将免费提供给拥有 Tread+ 跑步机的人。

客户可提前登记领取门卫。它仍在制造中，预计将在秋季上市。

在 2021 年召回之后，Peloton 告诉 Tread+ 跑步机所有者停止使用该产品。

新的防护装置采用分离式设计，当它接触到物体时会从跑步机上移开，从而关闭电源并使皮带减速。它旨在消除跑步机后部附近被夹住的可能性，这在过去是导致事故的主要原因。

该公司表示：“作为一个致力于为会员的健身之旅赋能的品牌，Peloton 始终致力于确保他们能够以最安全的方式获得我们世界一流的健身体验。”

除了 Tread+ 跑步机的问题，近年来其他安全问题也困扰着 Peloton。

在越来越多的担忧中，该公司最近几周改变了对召回的立场。

上周，当 CPSC 因安全问题召回 220 万辆 Peloton 自行车时，Peloton 表示合作，并表示“积极与 CPSC 合作解决这一问题并迅速合作确定补救措施非常重要”。

根据一份内部 Peloton 备忘录，型号为 PL01 的自行车的零件缺陷导致 12 人受伤，其中包括一次手腕骨折。

此前，该公司在与官员的合作方面进展缓慢，并对潜在的缺陷表示了不同意见。根据内部备忘录，Peloton 表示，尽管受影响的自行车数量相对较少，但它还是采取了行动，因为它是一家“会员至上的公司”。

本月早些时候，该公司公布了其第三财季的亏损超出预期，同时预测其订户数量将出现有史以来的首次下降。

Many workers need to take leave at some point to address their own health needs or to care for a loved one . Yet whether workers have access to those benefits is up to their employer or state.

This week, Democrats in Washington re-upped a push to create a national program to give every worker access to paid family and medical leave.

"After 10 years fighting for paid leave, we are still the only industrialized nation without this essential program," said Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand, DN.Y.

A law that lets workers take unpaid time off to take care of their loved ones or their own health — the Family and Medical Leave Act — recently reached its 30 th anniversary.

Now, Gillibrand and Rep. Rosa DeLauro, D-Conn., are putting forward an updated version of the Family and Medical Insurance Leave, or FAMILY, Act.

"Thirty years ago, we broke ground by enshrining the Family and Medical Leave Act into law, providing unpaid family and medical leave for working Americans," DeLauro said in a statement, referencing the law passed under President Bill Clinton.

"Let's break ground again by making it paid," DeLauro said.

What new paid family leave proposal would cover

The new version of the proposal comes after Democrats had previously reduced their proposal to four weeks' leave with the hopes of getting it included in a broader package.

The bill now includes partial income for up to 12 weeks' leave. The typical full-time worker would earn about two-thirds of their normal wages, while low-wage workers would be compensated for around 85%.

The plan covers leave for workers' and family members' serious health conditions, or the birth or adoption of a child.

The new version of the bill would provide leave for workers to address the effects of domestic violence or sexual assault.

Other updates to the bill aim to update the definition of the modern family.

That includes a broader range of caregiving relationships, including spouses, domestic or civil union partners, children of any age and their spouses, parents and their spouses, siblings and their spouses, grandparents and their spouses, grandchildren and their spouses, and other individuals related by either blood or kinship.

After 10 years fighting for paid leave, we are still the only industrialized nation without this essential program.
Kirsten Gillibrand
US senator from New York

The bill would cover any worker who has earned at least $2,000 in the past two years, regardless of whether those earnings are covered by Social Security taxes. It would also eliminate an unpaid waiting period for benefits, which previously made it so benefits were not available for the first five days of caregiving.

The proposal would be paid for through a 0.4% payroll tax that would apply to the Medicare taxable wage base.

Workers would still be able to receive paid leave through state programs , as long as the states can demonstrate they are at least as generous as the federal program.

'Some real momentum' on paid leave

Research has shown that enacting a federal paid family leave program would have positive benefits.

Workers missed out on roughly $28 billion more in wages between March 2020 and February 2022 compared to the previous two years, research from the Urban Institute has found.

But the challenge is getting bipartisan agreement on a plan. Support for the FAMILY Act in both houses has traditionally been Democrats, noted Kathleen Romig, director of Social Security and disability policy at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities.

"To get anything to get anything to move in this Congress, you need both Republicans and Democrats," Romig said.

House speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., at an August 2020 Washington, DC, rally organized by the “Paid Leave for All” cross-country bus tour.
安娜摇钱树 |盖蒂图片新闻 |盖蒂图片社

While Republicans have shown interest in implementing paid leave policies, a sticking point between the parties has been how to pay for those plans.

While Democrats have proposed funding paid leave through payroll taxes, Republicans have generally talked about funding such a plan by having people borrow against other benefits, such as Social Security benefits or child tax credits, Romig noted.

Still, there is some reason to be optimistic about paid leave, Romig said.

"While I don't think this particular bill is going to be passed into law this year, I also think there is some real momentum here," Romig said.

WASHINGTON — House Speaker Kevin McCarthy said Thursday he is optimistic that congressional negotiators could reach a deal to raise or suspend the debt ceiling in time to hold a House vote on it next week.

"I see the path that we can come to an agreement," McCarthy told reporters in the Capitol. "And I think we have a structure now and everybody's working hard, and I mean, we're working two or three times a day, then going back, getting more numbers."

Investors have been watching Washington closely this week for any signs of progress in the monthslong debt limit standoff.

White House negotiators huddled with McCarthy's team in the Capitol complex Thursday, continuing their efforts to hammer out a deal that needs to pass the Republican majority House and the Democratic-controlled Senate ahead of a potential June 1 deadline, the soonest date the Treasury could run out of cash to pay debts already incurred.

McCarthy declined to give reporters any new details about what exactly was being discussed behind closed doors. He said, "I don't think it's productive if you go write something and then everyone who is not in the room all get mad over things."

"I just believe where we were a week ago and where we are today is a much better place, because we've got the right people in the room discussing it in a very professional manner, with all the knowledge, all the background from all the different leaders," McCarthy added.

The comments amount to a remarkable shift in tone from the Republican House speaker, who until now has sounded more pessimistic than either the White House or congressional Democrats about the odds of a compromise that could win the support of his fractious caucus.

McCarthy's newfound optimism came after a key meeting at the White House on Tuesday, after which President Joe Biden dispatched two of his most trusted negotiators to launch a new round of talks: Presidential counselor Steve Ricchetti and Office of Management and Budget Director Shalanda Young.

Leading the talks on the Republican side is Louisiana Rep. Garret Graves, who worked as a committee staffer in the House and Senate before being elected to office in his own right.

Like Graves, Young also worked as a House staffer for many years. Together, they bring to the talks a first-hand knowledge of how to move complex legislation through the lower chamber.

Setting aside partisan rhetoric, McCarthy took time to praise on the White House team Thursday.

"I have the greatest respect for Shalanda and for Ricchetti. They are exceptionally, smart, tough, they are strong in their beliefs on the Democratic side, just as who we have in the room," he told reporters in the Capitol's Statuary Hall.

"They're working through it in a very professional manner, seeing where we can be able to raise the debt ceiling, taking concerns of what the House has, and others, and put a bill together that will become law," said McCarthy.

The House and Senate both kept their original plans to leave for the weekend on Thursday, a sign that the steady progress of talks was raising confidence among congressional leaders about an eventual deal.

The Senate is not scheduled to be back session until the last few days of May. But Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, DN.Y., advised members to be ready to return to the Capitol with 24 hours notice.

While McCarthy's apparent turnaround was welcome news for jittery markets, it set off warning bells for congressional Democrats.

Members of the president's own party have become increasingly worried this week that Biden is giving House Republicans the upper hand, despite the fact that Democrats control both the White House and the Senate.

House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries of New York warned that a key Republican demand Biden has said he is open to — stricter work requirements for some federal assistance programs — was a "nonstarter, period, full stop" for House Democrats.

In the Senate, meanwhile, a group of 11 Democrats sent Biden a letter Thursday, urging the president to keep open the option of invoking the 14th Amendment.

The amendment states in part that "the validity of the public debt of the United States ... shall not be questioned."

But the legal theory that the president can simply ignore the debt ceiling by citing the Constitution's requirement that the country pay its bills has not been tested in court.

Earlier this month, Biden said he had considered the 14th Amendment, but concluded that it would not prevent a default.

The growing frustration some Senate Democrats feel over the direction of the talks was on view at a Thursday press conference with some of the senators who signed the letter.

"If the bottom line is that the only deal to be had, that McCarthy will sign on to, is one in which ordinary families are savaged and in which the economy is flooded with fossil fuels, that is unacceptable," said Sen. Jeff Merkley of Oregon.

Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., who spearheaded the letter, complained that Senate Democrats were being kept in the dark about what was going on in the talks. He implied that Biden was caving on his long standing demand that House Republicans pass a debt ceiling hike with no strings attached.

"None of us are aware of exactly what is happening" in the talks, said Sanders. "I think what the president has insisted from day one is that there be a clean debt ceiling approach. And I think we all support that."

Asked whether he had communicated his concerns to the White House, Sanders replied, "Yeah," and refused to say more.

"It was a private conversation," he added.
